 I'd quite like to see the original translation of this, because that verse is one of the (many) more ambiguous ones in the bible. 
 
 Firstly, the most literal translation I can find of the first half says this: 
 "22 And when men strive, and have smitten a pregnant woman, and her children have come out, and there is no mischief,".
 The KJV has similar wording: 
 "22 If men strive, and hurt a woman with child, so that her fruit depart from her, and yet no mischief follow:".
 Several further translations of this verse take this to mean 'gives birth prematurely', as you have, but several others (1, 2, 3, 4) all have variants on the theme of "if a pregnant woman is hit so that she miscarries". This drastically changes your implied meaning of the passage.
 
 Secondly (and related to the first point), the verses don't specify to whom they are applying - is it the baby who must be injured for 'an eye for an eye' to apply, or is it the mother? There are several things here which imply that it is the mother. 
 1. Several of the various translations refer specifically to the mother being injured - eg 
 "When there's a fight and in the fight a pregnant woman is hit so that she miscarries but is not otherwise hurt"
 or 
 "Suppose a pregnant woman suffers a miscarriage as the result of an injury caused by someone who is fighting. If she isn't badly hurt, the one who injured her must pay whatever fine her husband demands and the judges approve. 23But if she is seriously injured, the payment will be life for life". 
 No translations that I could find referred specifically to the baby in this way.
 2. Judging by the 'miscarriage' translations, it makes no sense to refer to the infant; it has already miscarried. The only alternative is that it refers to the woman.
 3. The verse later specifically mentions 'tooth for tooth'. Seeing as a newborn baby (especially a premature one!) doesn't have any visible teeth, this makes no sense to apply it to the infant. Again, the only alternative is the woman.
 
 You have one interpretation. I have another. The two interpretation vastly change the implications of the passage.

 I would generally counsel against abortion even in earlier terms, except in cases where the baby will never survive (e.g. anencephaly), the mother's life is in danger, or where her long-term health will be jeopardized. Barring such circumstances, I don't think abortion is a moral way to go.
